awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Reassessing the role of the Great American Biotic Interchange in the evolution of the raccoon family
awd_abstract_narration:
The Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI) was a major biogeographic event that connected the terrestrial animal communities of North and South America via the closure of the Panamanian Isthmus. Geological evidence and the fossil record have suggested that the closure of the isthmus occurred 3 million years ago (mya), but more recent studies suggest a much older age for the formation of a landbridge between North and South America, around 15 mya. Among mammals of North American origin, the raccoon family (Procyonidae), which also includes coatis, kinkajous, olingos, and ringtails, has one of the longest histories in South America. The fossil record shows that an extinct member of this group was the first North American mammal to immigrate to South America, approximately 7-9 mya. While the prevailing hypothesis states that immigration of modern members of this group took place 3 mya, recent estimates based on DNA sequence data revealed that this family has had a much longer tenure in South America. This study will more thoroughly test competing hypotheses regarding the process and timing of evolution of this group, with the potential to revise our understanding of mammal evolution in the Neotropics, while contributing to advancement in the fields of genomics, systematics, taxonomy, and biogeography, as well as promoting the professional development of an early-career female STEM researcher. 

This project will use an integrative approach to test competing hypotheses based on genomic analyses of museum specimens, morphometrics, and biogeographic modeling. Ancient DNA techniques in combination with high-throughput sequencing methods will be used to sequence mitochondrial genomes as well as to sample the nuclear genome using a novel intron-capture microarray. Morphometric data will be analyzed separately and in conjunction with comparative genomic data to test hypotheses regarding procyonid evolution and revise the taxonomy of this group. A new biogeographic model for the evolution of the raccoon family that accommodates the most recent DNA and geological evidence will be tested against the traditional fossil-based hypothesis, and will integrate phylogenetic data to reassess the tempo and geographic pattern of diversification associated with the GABI. Results will be shared through scientific publications co-authored by the PI, Co-PI, and collaborators. Genomic and morphological data, protocols, scripts and parameters used in the analyses will be made publicly available through the electronic repositories of NCBI?s Genbank and Dryad.

por.por_cntn:
The Neotropics is one of the most diverse regions in the planet, with a complex history of biogeographic and climatic events shaping its diversity. After the breakup from the supercontinent Gondwana, South American remained isolated for tens of millions of years since its separation from Antarctica. That isolation ended with a major geological and biological event known as the Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI), which connected the faunal assemblages of North and South America via the closure of the Panamanian Isthmus. Currently, there is much debate in the scientific community regarding the timing of the GABI: geological evidence and fossil records have suggested that the closure of the isthmus occurred ca. 3 million years ago (mya), but recent studies suggest a much older age for the formation of a landbridge between North and South America, around 15 mya. During the GABI, fossil evidence indicates that 17 northern and 21 southern mammal families crossed the isthmus. Among mammals, the family Procyonidae (raccoon family) has one of the longest histories in South America. Procyonidae is one of sixteen families in the order Carnivora, comprising six genera of medium-sized mammals (raccoons, kinkajous, olingos, ringtails and coatis), with 14 recognized species and about 75 recognized subspecies. The fossil record shows that an extinct member of this group was the first North American mammal to immigrate to South America, around 7-9 mya, but recent estimates based on DNA analyses revealed that this family has a much older history in South America.

In this study, we evaluated alternative hypotheses regarding the timing of colonization of South America by North American mammals using the raccoon family, Procyonidae (Mammalia, Carnivora) as a study group.  We aimed to understand the place and timing of diversification of procyonids, as well as assess if the current classification of this group is supported by new evidence derived from morphology and different sets of genomics markers. We adopted an integrative approach based on museomics (genomic analyses of museum specimens), traditional morphometrics, biogeographic modeling and whole genome sequencing. We focused on three groups of procyonids, coatis (Nasua and Nasuella), kinkajous (Potos) and raccoons (Procyon), with ranges spanning north and south of the Panama Isthmus. We sequenced complete mitogenomes and nuclear ultraconserved elements (UCEs) of 75 museum specimens distributed across their range, including samples that were collected more than 100 years ago.

For coatis, our mitogenome results indicate that some populations of brown-nosed coatis (Nasua nasua) have been separated for more than five million years. There was some agreement between the mitogenome and UCE results, but the UCE lacked the resolution provided by the mitogenome dataset, which can be justified by the overall slower mutation rate in the nuclear genome. The morphological dataset was not powerful enough to identify intraspecific differences for this species, and the currently described subspecies do not match the genetic splits found in our study. Among procyonids, coatis have the oldest history in South America (around 8 mya). In contrast, the mitogenome phylogenetic results and the subspecific designations are in agreement with regard to the kinkajou (Potos flavus), but the UCE dataset also did not provide as much resolution as the mitogenome. Surprisingly, the kinkajou history in South America was estimated at around 3.5 mya, which agrees with the traditional view of GABI. The split between the North and South American raccoon species was also estimated around 3.5 mya. Overall, our results show that procyonids have a long and complex history in South America, with different groups arriving at distinct times. Particularly, the Andean region seems to play an important role in the diversification of both coatis and kinkajous.

In addition to the proposed project, we sequenced the whole genomes of the kinkajou and the North American raccoon, the first procyonids to date, closing a gap of 30 million years (my) in the tree of life and covering more than 20 my of evolutionary history within the family. Also, the genomes can be used in applied studies of disease dynamics and will help elucidate host-pathogen interactions including the genetics of disease susceptibility, in relation to the already-sequenced genome of the raccoon rabies virus.

Those results have been shared with the scientific community through presentations at scientific meetings and conferences, and four manuscripts are currently being prepared for publication by the end of the year. Our findings have also been shared with the general public in several outreach events both at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute, Smithsonian National Zoo and the National Museum of Natural History. This project also provided training opportunities for one minority female graduate student (co-PI) in the fields of genomics and bioinformatics, as well as two female minority interns co-mentored by her, thus advancing discovery while promoting the training and learning.
